importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Lindsay Sandiford was arrested in 2012 at Bali's airport, marking the start of her imprisonment for drug smuggling.
Indonesia’s highest court upheld Lindsay Sandiford’s death sentence in 2013, a pivotal moment in the case that led to international intervention.
Shahab Shahabadi was arrested in 2014 and began serving a life sentence, highlighting the long-term consequences of drug trafficking convictions in Indonesia.
The repatriation agreement between the UK and Indonesia was signed on October 21, 2025, leading to the potential saving of both prisoners’ lives.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline from 2012 to 2025 captures the duration of Lindsay Sandiford’s imprisonment and the years of international diplomatic effort leading to her repatriation.

keyTakeAways: A British grandmother, Lindsay Sandiford, was sentenced to death in Indonesia for drug smuggling but spared from execution through a bilateral repatriation agreement with the UK.
Another British prisoner, Shahab Shahabadi, is serving a life sentence for methamphetamine trafficking and is also being repatriated under the agreement.
The UK and Indonesia signed a repatriation deal to return foreign nationals imprisoned for drug-related offenses, reflecting growing international concern over capital punishment for drug crimes.

Indonesia has one of the world’s strictest drug laws and maintains a high number of death row inmates, especially for drug-related offenses, with over 530 people on death row and nearly 100 being foreigners.
The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime has highlighted Indonesia as a major drug smuggling hub due to its youth-targeted drug networks, despite its strict laws.
This case draws attention to the role of international diplomacy in preventing the execution of foreign nationals in countries with mandatory death sentences.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central figure in the repatriation deal, facing execution until the UK-Indonesia agreement saved her life.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A British grandmother, Lindsay Sandiford, was sentenced to death in Indonesia for smuggling cocaine in 2013, while another British man, Shahab Shahabadi, has been serving a life sentence since 2014 for methamphetamine trafficking. Both are now being repatriated to the UK under a bilateral agreement signed between the UK and Indonesia on October 21, 2025. The deal, led by UK Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper and Indonesian Senior Minister of Law Yusril Ihza Mahendra, reflects growing international concern over capital punishment for drug offenses, especially in countries with strict drug laws like Indonesia, which has over 530 death row inmates, nearly 100 of them foreign nationals. This case draws attention to the role of diplomacy in preventing the execution of foreign nationals and underscores Indonesia’s status as a major drug smuggling hub despite its harsh sentencing laws.
title: British grandmother spared firing squad in repatriation deal with Indonesia
